head.supplied: Ehrenbreitstein, ¶ Dec. 23rd, 1897. ¶ My dearest Lu, ¶ ¶ I meant to have written for you to get a few lines from home at Xmas, but get so few quiet hours for it now, & then Mr. Potter sent the box &...

div.p: From Clara Wehl to Louisa Mattheissen
RB MSS Mnumber, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens, Melbourne.

Transcribed 21 Febraury 1990. Corrected 16 October 1992.
Ehrenbreitstein,
Clara Wehl’s property near Millicent, SA.
Dec. 23rd, 1897.

I meant to have written for you to get a few lines from home at Xmas, but get so few quiet hours for it now, & then Mr. Potter sent the box & I waited till I saw the contents, so I could tell you, & you are the first one too. "The Crown & Coronet are very grand, they have such immense stones all around them, that I can scarcely imagine them to be real; the little diamonds do not play in colours either, but then I am no judge. (the color of stones are, blue, red, yellow, green, & 2 little diamonds between each, red velvet on top). You see I know you like particulars. Do not tell anyone about them, if it becomes known I have them they would not be safe. The 2 Orders left us are silver & gold, without precious stones. Then there are 2 framed addresses, one in a beautiful broad gold frame large size, of that the glass got broken. 3 Cozies for tea & coffee pots. one writing map, 2 cushions, 1 pr slippers, 1 scarf, 1 crochet necktie, 1 stuffed parrot, letterweight & pen brush, sachet, 1 small china tea pot, & a three cornered pincushion." You see they are all trifles, beside the bequests we knew of.
